skill.name: Generate Image
skill.description: Generate or edit high-quality images using OpenRouter's image generation models including FLUX.2 Pro and Gemini 3 Pro. For general-purpose image generation including photos, illustrations, artwork, visual assets, concept art, and any image that is not a technical diagram or schematic.
skill.summary: Generate and edit AI images using FLUX and Gemini models via OpenRouter API
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 99 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is a legitimate image generation tool using OpenRouter API. The static scanner flagged standard API key handling, base64 image encoding, and documentation code blocks as suspicious patterns. No malicious intent or exfiltration behavior was found. The code performs exactly as documented - generating images via API calls.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Code execution + Network + Credential access" at multiple:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The 'dangerous combination' heuristic triggered on standard API key handling and network requests. The code accesses OPENROUTER_API_KEY from .env (legitimate authentication) and makes HTTPS requests to OpenRouter API (documented image generation). This is the expected behavior for an API-based image generation tool, not obfuscation or evasion.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Network + Credentials + Evasion techniques" at multiple:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Base64 encoding of images is standard practice for API communication with image generation services. The credential access is for authentication to OpenRouter. There are no evasion techniques - the code clearly documents its network behavior and API endpoints in both code and documentation.

Line 23 calls check_env_file() which reads OPENROUTER_API_KEY from .env for OpenRouter authentication. This is standard practice for API-based tools, not secret exfiltration. The API key is used locally for the image generation request.

All env_access findings relate to reading OPENROUTER_API_KEY for authenticating to OpenRouter API. This is legitimate API authentication, not credential theft. The API key is used to call the image generation endpoint and never transmitted to third parties.

The code reads .env file to locate OPENROUTER_API_KEY for local API authentication. This is the standard pattern for API-based tools. There is no evidence of data exfiltration - the .env access is explicitly for configuration and documented in SKILL.md.

Line 86 is within a docstring describing function parameters. The word 'key' appears in the context 'API key' (authentication credential), not cryptographic operations. The static scanner misidentified 'key' as cryptographic reference. No actual cryptographic code exists.

Lines 211-212 are argparse help text. Line 240 is argparse help for --api-key parameter. The word 'key' refers to API authentication credentials, not cryptographic keys. No cryptographic algorithms are used in this code.

Line 71 writes base64-decoded image data to a file specified by the user. This is the core function of the skill - saving generated images. The output path is user-controlled via command line argument, not automatic exfiltration to hidden locations.

base64.b64decode() decodes image data returned from OpenRouter API. Base64 encoding is the standard format for transmitting binary image data in JSON API responses. This is normal image handling, not obfuscation.

Line 34 of SKILL.md contains 'scripts/generate_image.py' in backticks - this is markdown code formatting, not shell execution. Backticks in documentation mark inline code, not backtick command substitution. No actual shell execution occurs.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: "Ruby/shell backtick execution" at SKILL.md:36-149 (multiple lines)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: All 44 external_commands findings in SKILL.md are markdown code blocks showing bash command examples for users. These are documented usage examples, not executed code. The backticks and code fences are standard documentation formatting for showing command syntax.

Line 144 uses requests.post() to call OpenRouter API endpoint for image generation. This is the intended functionality of the skill. The endpoint https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/chat/completions is documented and legitimate.

Line 111 displays 'https://openrouter.ai/keys' as a help message directing users to get their API key. This is a legitimate reference to the OpenRouter key management page, not a C2 or exfiltration endpoint.
Line 145 is the OpenRouter API endpoint for chat completions. This is the expected, documented endpoint for image generation via OpenRouter. Not a suspicious hardcoded URL.
Lines 55 and 168 reference https://openrouter.ai/keys and https://openrouter.ai/models. These are legitimate documentation links for OpenRouter API configuration. Not suspicious endpoints.
SKILL.md documentation explains that OPENROUTER_API_KEY is required and shows example .env configuration. This is standard documentation for API-based skills, not credential access patterns.
SKILL.md documents how the skill finds and uses the .env file for API configuration. This is legitimate documentation of the configuration pattern. No sensitive data is being accessed or transmitted.

All crypto findings in SKILL.md reference 'API key' (authentication credential) or 'key' in general contexts. The static scanner misidentifies any occurrence of 'key' as a cryptographic reference. No cryptographic algorithms are mentioned or used.

content.user_title: Generate AI images with FLUX and Gemini
content.value_statement: Create high-quality images for presentations, documents, and publications using AI models. Generate original artwork or edit existing images with simple text prompts. Access FLUX and Gemini models through OpenRouter API.
actual_capabilities: Generate images from text prompts using FLUX and Gemini models
Edit existing images with natural language instructions
Save generated images as PNG files with custom output paths
Choose between multiple image generation models for quality or speed
Support for PNG, JPEG, GIF, and WebP input formats for editing
limitations: Requires OpenRouter API key with credits for image generation
Cannot generate technical diagrams, schematics, or flowcharts
Generation time varies from 5-30 seconds depending on model
Output limited to PNG format for generated images

use_cases.title: Create figures for papers
use_cases.description: Generate conceptual illustrations for research papers and presentations with scientific visualization style.

use_cases.title: Produce visual assets
use_cases.description: Create illustrations, artwork, and marketing visuals for documents, websites, and campaigns.

use_cases.title: Design presentation graphics
use_cases.description: Generate hero images, backgrounds, and visual aids for slides, posters, and educational materials.

prompt_templates.title: Basic generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an image of [subject] in [style] style, [additional details]

prompt_templates.title: Scientific illustration
prompt_templates.prompt: [Scientific concept description], scientific illustration style, clean and professional, suitable for academic presentation

prompt_templates.title: Image editing
prompt_templates.prompt: Edit this image: [specific instructions for changes to the input image]

prompt_templates.title: Model selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate [description] using model black-forest-labs/flux.2-pro, output to [filename].png

output_examples.input: Generate an image of a molecular structure with glowing bonds, scientific illustration style

best_practices: Be specific in prompts - describe subjects, styles, lighting, and composition details
Use gemini-3-pro or flux.2-pro models for image editing tasks
Check OpenRouter pricing page to understand model costs before generation
anti_patterns: Do not use for technical diagrams, flowcharts, or schematics - use scientific-schematics skill instead
Do not share API keys in prompts or scripts - store in .env file
Do not expect photorealistic output from FLUX.2-flex - use Pro models for higher quality

faq.question: Which model should I use for image editing?
faq.answer: Use google/gemini-3-pro-image-preview or black-forest-labs/flux.2-pro. Both support image editing capabilities.

faq.question: How do I set up my OpenRouter API key?
faq.answer: Create a .env file with OPENROUTER_API_KEY=your-key or set the environment variable before running.

faq.question: Can I edit images with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, use the --input flag to provide an existing image and describe your editing instructions in the prompt.

faq.question: What image formats are supported?
faq.answer: Input images can be PNG, JPEG, GIF, or WebP. Generated images are saved as PNG files.

faq.question: Why should I not use this for diagrams?
faq.answer: This skill is designed for artistic images and photos. Use the scientific-schematics skill for flowcharts and diagrams.

faq.question: How long does image generation take?
faq.answer: Generation typically takes 5-30 seconds depending on the model selected and current API load.
